title: How to Cook Kale

steps.headline: Heat water in a pot with a steamer.
steps.description: Place a medium-sized pot on the stove and pour an inch of water in the bottom. Turn the heat on to medium-high so the water begins to simmer. Ensure that your metal steamer basket will fit in the pot. The pot should also have  a tight-fitting lid.

steps.headline: Wash and tear the kale.
steps.description: Wash the kale under cold water to remove any dirt or grit. Remove the tough stem from each leaf of kale. You can either tear it out or carefully use a sharp knife to slice the stem away. Tear or chop the kale into bite-sized pieces. Discard the stems or save them for another recipe. You can dry the kale if it makes it easier for you to tear or chop.

steps.headline: Steam the kale in the steamer basket.
steps.description: Once the water in your saucepan is simmering (bubbling a little), put the kale in the steamer basket. Set the steamer basket into your saucepan and cover the pot with the tight-fitting lid. Let the kale steam over medium-high heat for 5 to 10 minutes. Stir it occasionally so it steams evenly. You can taste the kale and season it with a vinegar or squeeze of lemon juice. For easy removal, just use tongs to scoop the kale out of the steamer basket. This will also help any water drip off of the kale.

steps.headline: Serve the steamed kale.
steps.description:
Place the steamed kale in a serving bowl. Drizzle a vinaigrette or dressing over the kale and gently stir it to combine. You can serve the steamed kale while it's still warm or let it cool to room temperature before serving. Good choices for dressings include:
Bleu cheese dressing
Caesar
Greek vinaigrette
Hummus

steps.headline: Wash and cut the kale.
steps.description: Wash a bunch of kale under cold water until all the grit and dirt is completely washed away. Lay the kale leaves on top of each other on a cutting board. Hold the kale in place while you cut the kale into 1/4 inch strips. If the kale was very dirty, you can wash and rinse the kale again after you've cut it.

steps.headline: Heat aromatics on the stove.
steps.description: Heat a large saucepan over medium-high heat and add a few tablespoons of olive oil. Once the oil shimmers, add 1 sliced onion. Saute the onion for 3 to 4 minutes and stir in 2 or 3 cloves of minced garlic. Let the aromatic mixture cook another minute. For a little spice, consider stirring in a pinch of red chili pepper flakes.

steps.headline: Stir in and cook the kale.
steps.description: Add the cut kale to the mixture in your saucepan and add enough chicken or vegetable stock to cover the kale by about 1/2 an inch. You'll probably need about 3 cups of stock. Bring the kale to a simmer and cover the pan. Let the kale continue to cook for 30 minutes or until it's tender. You can add extra stock or water if you'd like to serve a little of the aromatic liquid with the kale. Taste the boiled kale and add salt and pepper to taste.

steps.headline: Serve the boiled kale.
steps.description: Boiled kale goes well with a hearty bread or toast. Try rubbing a little garlic on a piece of rustic toast. Top the toast with a fried egg and place some of the boiled kale on top. You could also sprinkle toasted breadcrumbs on top of the boiled kale, if you're short on time and need a quick serving idea.

steps.headline: Heat oil in a saucepan.
steps.description: Select a large heavy saucepan and heat it over medium-high heat. Add several tablespoons of olive oil the pan and let the oil heat until it starts shimmering. Ensure that your pan is large enough to hold all of the kale. If the pan is too small, the kale won't cook evenly or could take much longer to saute.

steps.headline: Add garlic, stock, and kale.
steps.description: Once the oil is shimmering, add a few cloves of minced garlic and let it cook for about 30 seconds. Turn the heat up to high and add 1/2 cup of chicken or vegetable stock. Stir in the kale so the mixture is combined. If you don't have any stock, you can use water. You may just need to add more seasoning to the sauteed kale.

steps.headline: Cook the kale for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the saucepan with a tight-fitting lid and cook the kale on high for 5 minutes. Take the lid off of the pot and keep cooking the kale for a few minutes until the stock or water evaporates. Season the kale to taste and serve it right away. You'll want to salt and pepper the kale. Sauteed kale also goes well with a few tablespoons of red wine vinegar.

steps.headline: Serve the sauteed kale.
steps.description: You can easily serve sauteed kale on its own as a side dish or include it in an entree. Stir sauteed kale into cooked pasta or soup to add instant flavor and nutrition. Consider substituting collard greens or chard with sauteed kale the next time you're planning a menu. You could also saute apples and bacon to stir into the sauteed kale. Sprinkle the dish with pecans or walnuts and serve it while it's still warm.

steps.headline: Heat the oven and prepare your baking sheet.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 375 degrees F (190 C). Select a large baking sheet with rimmed sides. The rimmed sides will keep the kale from sliding off as you transfer the sheet from the oven. If you don't have a rimmed baking sheet, you could use a large roasting pan. Just take care not to overfill the pan or the kale with steam instead of roast.

steps.headline: Wash and chop the kale.
steps.description: Wash the kale thoroughly to remove all dirt and grit. Pat the kale dry and tear or cut away the thick stems. Chop the kale into large pieces and dry them again with a clean kitchen towel or paper towel. To quickly dry the kale, try spinning it in a salad spinner until all the water is removed from the kale.

steps.headline: Season and bake the kale.
steps.description: Place the chopped kale pieces in a large mixing bowl. Drizzle the kale with one tablespoon of olive oil, one clove of garlic, and salt and pepper. Toss the seasonings together with the kale so the kale is completely covered. Spread the kale on the baking sheet and bake it for 15 to 20 minutes. You should stir it every five minutes, until the kale is crispy and a bit dark in color. The kale doesn't need to be arranged in a single layer on the baking sheet. As the kale roasts, it will shrink down in size.

steps.headline: Serve the roasted kale.
steps.description: For the crispiest roasted kale, serve the kale right after you've removed it from the oven. Roasted kale works well as part of a cheese spread or crudité platter. For example, you could serve the roasted kale alongside pita chips and hummus or a veggie tray. Roasted kale does not stay crispy for more than a day or two so try to eat the pieces quickly. If you must store them, place them in an airtight container for a few days.
